did.unittitle: UW-Milwaukee School of Information Studies Records, 1956-2014

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. School of Information Studies

physdesc.label: Quantity
physdesc.extent: plus additions of 3.2 cubic ft. (5 boxes) and 2,116 digital files (174 MB)

extref.corpname: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries, Archives Department

did.abstract: Records of the school and its predecessors. Most of the collection documents the daily administration of the school such as curriculum development, staffing, funding, and organization changes. Records detailing the process of the school's accreditation by the American Library Association contain correspondence, reports, credentials, statistics, course syllabi, and on-site visit reports. The collection also contains unrestricted summaries of teaching evaluations. Other miscellaneous records document the school's commitment to the inner city user, affirmative action, committees of the school, and the student and alumni associations.

bioghist.p: The Department of Library Science was made a department in the School of Education in 1956, with Donald Woods as chairperson. The Department of Library Science was transferred from the School of Education to the College of Letters & Science in 1965. The University of Wisconsin Board of Regents authorized the creation of the School of Library and Information Science on July 1, 1966. In the fall of 1966, the first graduate library science program began and the first library science degrees were granted in June 1967. From 1966 until 1970-the school offered two programs: Master of Arts in Library Science and Master of Science in Information Science. The information science degree was dropped in 1973 and the school was renamed the School of Library Science. The school received ALA accreditation in July 1976. In spring 1981, the program became the School of Library and Information Science. In February 1984, the school's master's degree was officially changed to Master of Library and Information Science. The school began offering a bachelor's degree in Information Studies in 1995. In 2001, the school changed its name once more, this time to the School of Information Studies. The School of Information Studies also began offering a Bachelor’s of Science and Information Resources in 1995.

bioghist.head: Chairs, Directors, and Deans of the School and its Predecessors

scopecontent.p: Records of the dean of the school and its predecessors. Most of the collection documents the daily administration of the school such as curriculum development, staffing, funding, and organization changes. Records detailing the process of the school's accreditation by the American Library Association (ALA) contain correspondence, reports, credentials, statistics, course syllabi, and on-site visit reports. The collection also contains unrestricted summaries of teaching evaluations. Other miscellaneous records document the school's commitment to the inner city user, affirmative action, committees of the school, the student and alumni associations.

The collection consists of accreditation files that include material such as correspondence, credentials of the faculty, reports, statistics and other information gathered at the request of the ALA. Faculty memos detail plans for accreditation visits, personnel changes, and graduate school standards for library education. Correspondence between SOIS and the UWM administration is largely routine, providing updates on the accreditation process.

The dean's correspondence contains items that were sent between the dean and the SLIS faculty concerning funding, the curriculum, and the program in general. There is also some correspondence from students, administration, other library schools and libraries. There are also several folders containing information regarding the School's relocation in Bolton Hall.

The collection also contains records concerning the Association of American Library Schools, of which the UWM SOIS was a member. Included are meeting agendas and minutes, conference information, and other correspondence relevant to being a member school.

The memoranda document the daily activity of the school with memos between the faculty and staff, as well as with the university administration. The memoranda files also contain other documents, such as applications for study and grievance procedures.

Also included are self-studies which were conducted as part of the process of ALA accreditation, and the reports reveal much about the administrative structure, faculty, renaming, resources, and staff of the school.

Teaching evaluations list the professor/instructor, the name of the course, date, and the students' responses to the questionnaires. There is also some miscellaneous material about SOIS efforts to improve inner city library service; the SLIS student and alumni organizations; colloquia (speakers) the school sponsored; and minutes from the various committees. Several folders contain information pertaining to the Information Technology 2000 Computer Training Program (IT2000).

arrangement.p: This collection was received in, and is organized in, multiple parts. Additional materials have not been physically or intellectually arranged and interfiled, and researchers may need to consult more than one part of the collection to locate similar materials.
The collection contains three additional accessions.

item.ref: Accession 2008-072: Milwaukee Teachers Education Center materials, 1975-2002
Accession 2013-024: Subject, Personnel, and Accreditation Digital Files, 1990-2003

otherfindaid.p: Finding aid for the personnel files in boxes 8-12 available in the Archives.

A spreadsheet with file-level information on the electronic records is available in the Archives department. The spreadsheet contains information on file title (where applicable), author, dates created, modified, and printed, file formats, number of pages, and software used to create the file. The files were inadvertently altered during transfer, so CreateDate and FileModifyDate fields may not include correct information. Additional technical metadata is available; consult an archivist for more information.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material in the UWM Libraries

archref.unittitle: UW-Milwaukee Office of the Provost and Vice Chancellor for Academic Affairs Records

accessrestrict.p: Electronic files must be viewed on computers in the Archives. Contact an archivist for more information. The unclassified personnel files in boxes 8-12, the search and screen committee materials in box 1 of accession 2011-041, and the academic appeals files and search and screen committee files in box 2 of accession 2013-024 are restricted in accordance with UWM Personnel File Policy S-42. Access to the records is regulated by Section III. A.2 and III. A.3. The files in box 23 are restricted in accordance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 (FERPA). See an Archivist for more information. There are no access restrictions on the rest of the collection, which is open to all members of the public in accordance with state law.

userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming with the laws of libel, privacy, and copyright which may be involved in the use of this collection (Wisconsin Statutes 19.21-19.39).

acqinfo.p: The school transferred the collection to the Archives prior to 1989. The School of Library and Information Science transferred additional accessions in 1999 and 2004. Accession 2008-057 was transferred in April 2009; accession 2008-072 in June 2009; accession 2009-006 in July 2009, and accession 2010-035 in January 2011. The School transferred additional materials to the Archives in April 2009 (accession 2008-057), June 2011 (accession 2010-063), May 2012 (accession 2011-041), and November 2013 (accession 2013-024).

processinfo.p: Theresa Larson began processing the collection at the Archives in August 1993. Julee Bokelman completed the reprocessing in September-October 1993. The collection originally consisted of 18 series and unprocessed accessions. Jeremy Brett added several files in February 2007, and processed accessions 1999-003, 1999-008, 1999-052, and 2004-028 in April-May 2007. Denise Gergetz processed accession 2008-057 in June 2009 (Brad Houston supervised). Matt Sherman processed the paper portion of accession 2008-072 in January 2010 (Brad Houston supervised). Sarah Phillips processed accession 2009-006 in June 2010 (Brad Houston supervised). Charles Welborn processed additional material in August 2012. Brad Houston processed some additional material in November 2012 and May 2013 (accession 2010-035). Brad Houston processed some additional material in December 2014. Molly Whiteside (supervised by Christel Maass) processed accessions 2008-057, 2010-063, and 2014-024 (boxes 26-30) in November and December 2015.
The collection title was changed on April 2, 2010 to reflect a name change from School of Library and Information Science to the most current name in the records.

processinfo.head: Preservation Information
processinfo.p: A copy of the electronic records was migrated to Open Document Format [.odf] for preservation in May 2012 using the National Archives of Australia's Digital Preservation Recorder.

phystech.p: As of May 23, 2013, all electronic files were accessible on a Intel Core 2 Duo CPU (2.33 GHz, 1.95 GB RAM) running Windows XP Professional Version 2002, with Service Pack 3. Software used to access the files includes Microsoft Office 2007, Firefox v. 21.0, and Adobe Reader XI.
The collection includes records in the following file formats:

did.abstract: Materials related to a School Library Media Certification offered by SOIS in conjunction with the Milwaukee Teachers Education Center (MTEC), which ran between 2001-2004. Accession includes memoranda related to the establishment of the program.

Additions of subject, accreditation, and search and screen files, dating from 1982 to 2009. Records include course syllabi from 2001-2009, minutes of various SOIS and SOIS-related committees, and presentations for SOIS' ALA reaccreditation visit in 2003. The largest part of the collection is comprised of photograph albums from 1982-2012. Photos include portraits, candid photos of faculty and staff, and specific events; many photos in the albums are identified with post-it notes or by SOIS staff annotations on the reverse.

Additions of subject, personnel, and accreditation files, dating from 1990 to 2003. Paper files include copies of faculty committee minutes and agendas, reports, organization charts, correspondence files for events and programs sponsored by SOIS (including the Ted Samore Lecture and awards ceremonies), course syllabi, and promotional material for SOIS. The electronic files contain similar materials, but for more recent timeframes than represented in the paper files, suggesting the school's move to electronic documents as official records; most of the folders are meeting minutes and attachments, but also included are course syllabi and a copy of the website created for SOIS' ALA reaccreditation process in 2003.
